ai-sn8:1.1.2_0: At one time Venerable Vaṅgīsa was staying near Āḷavī, at the Aggāḷava Tree-shrine, together with his mentor, Venerable Nigrodhakappa.
ai-sn8:1.1.3_0: Now at that time Vaṅgīsa was junior, recently gone forth. He had been left behind to look after the dwelling.
ai-sn8:1.1.4_0: Then several women dressed in all their finery went to the monastery at Aggāḷava in order to inspect the dwelling.
ai-sn8:1.1.5_0: When Vaṅgīsa saw them he became dissatisfied, with lust infecting his mind.
ai-sn8:1.1.8_0: that I’ve become dissatisfied, with lust infecting my mind. How is it possible for someone else to dispel my discontent and give rise to satisfaction?
ai-sn8:1.1.9_0: Why don’t I do it myself?”
ai-sn8:1.1.10_0: Then, on the occasion of dispelling his own discontent and giving rise to satisfaction, he recited these verses:
ai-sn8:1.2.2_0: from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-sn8:1.2.4_0: because they’ve given up these things.
ai-sn8:1.3.1_0: Even if a thousand mighty princes and great archers,
ai-sn8:1.4.4_0: for I stand firm in the teaching.
ai-sn8:1.5.1_0: I heard this with my own ears
ai-sn8:1.5.2_0: from the Buddha, Kinsman of the Sun,
ai-sn8:1.5.3_0: about the path going to extinguishment;
ai-sn8:1.6.1_0: Wicked One, if you come near me
ai-sn8:1.6.3_0: I’ll make sure that you, Death,
ai-sn8:1.6.4_0: you won’t even see the path I take.”
ai-sn8:2.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying nearby.
ai-sn8:2.1.1_1: Venerable Vaṅgīsa was staying near Āḷavī, at the Aggāḷava Tree-shrine, together with his mentor, Venerable Nigrodhakappa.
ai-sn8:2.1.2_0: Now at that time Venerable Nigrodha, after the meal, on his return from alms-round, he entered his dwelling and went out to meet the time.
ai-sn8:2.1.3_0: And at that time Venerable Vaṅgīsa became dissatisfied, as lust infected his mind.
ai-sn8:2.1.6_0: that I’ve become dissatisfied, with lust infecting my mind.
ai-sn8:2.1.6_1: How could it possibly be otherwise?
ai-sn8:2.1.7_0: Why don’t I do it myself?”
ai-sn8:2.1.8_0: Then, on the occasion of dispelling his own discontent and giving rise to satisfaction, he recited these verses:
ai-sn8:2.2.2_0: Everywhere, and the thoughts of the lay life,
ai-sn8:2.2.4_0: unentangled, undesiring: that’s a real mendicant.
ai-sn8:2.3.1_0: Whether on this earth or in the sky,
ai-sn8:2.3.2_0: whatever in the world is included in form
ai-sn8:2.3.3_0: wears out, it is all impermanent;
ai-sn8:2.3.4_0: the thoughtful live having comprehended this truth.
ai-sn8:2.4.1_0: People are bound to their attachments,
ai-sn8:2.4.2_0: in regard to what is seen, and sensed,
ai-sn8:2.4.3_0: Here desire for men to be dispelled by desire (inside.)
ai-sn8:2.4.4_0: He who does not cling to, he who is called a sage for him.
ai-sn8:2.5.1_0: Attached to the sixty wrong views, and full of their own opinions,
ai-sn8:2.5.2_0: ordinary people are fixed in wrong principles.
ai-sn8:2.5.3_0: But that mendicant wouldn’t join a sectarian group,
ai-sn8:2.5.4_0: still less would they utter lewd speech.
ai-sn8:2.6.2_0: free of deceit, alert, without envy,
ai-sn8:2.6.3_0: a sage has reached the state of peace;
ai-sn8:3.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Vaṅgīsa was staying near Āḷavī, at the Aggāḷava Tree-shrine, together with his mentor, Venerable Nigrodhakappa.
ai-sn8:3.1.2_0: Now at that time Venerable Vaṅgīsa looked down upon other good-hearted mendicants because of his own poetic virtuosity.
ai-sn8:3.1.5_0: that I look down on other good-hearted mendicants because of my own poetic virtuosity.”
ai-sn8:3.1.6_0: Then, on the occasion of arousing remorse in himself, he recited these verses:
ai-sn8:3.2.2_0: Completely abandon the different kinds of conceit!
ai-sn8:3.2.3_0: Besotted with the different kinds of conceit,
ai-sn8:3.2.4_0: you’ve had regrets for a long time.
ai-sn8:3.3.1_0: Smeared by smears and slain by conceit,
ai-sn8:3.3.2_0: they grieve for a long time.
ai-sn8:3.3.3_0: Those people wander for a long time.
ai-sn8:3.3.4_0: they grieve for a long time.
ai-sn8:3.4.1_0: But a mendicant who practices rightly,
ai-sn8:3.4.2_0: winner of the path, never grieves.
ai-sn8:3.4.3_0: They enjoy happiness and a good reputation,
ai-sn8:3.4.4_0: and they rightly call him a ‘Seer of Truth’.
ai-sn8:3.5.1_0: So don’t be hard-hearted, be energetic,
ai-sn8:3.5.2_0: with hindrances given up, be pure.
ai-sn8:3.5.3_0: Then with conceit given up completely,
ai-sn8:3.5.4_0: use knowledge to make an end, and be at peace.”
ai-sn8:4.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn8:4.1.2_0: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms with Venerable Vaṅgīsa as his second monk.
ai-sn8:4.1.3_0: And at that time Venerable Vaṅgīsa became dissatisfied, as lust infected his mind.
ai-sn8:4.1.4_0: Then he addressed Ānanda in verse:
ai-sn8:4.2.1_0: “I’ve got a burning desire for pleasure;
ai-sn8:4.2.4_0: tell me how to quench the flames.”
ai-sn8:4.3.2_0: because of a perversion of perception.
ai-sn8:4.3.3_0: Turn away from the feature of things
ai-sn8:4.4.1_0: See all conditioned phenomena as other,
ai-sn8:4.4.3_0: Extinguish the great fire of lust,
ai-sn8:4.4.4_0: don’t burn up again and again.
ai-sn8:4.5.3_0: With mindfulness immersed in the body,
ai-sn8:4.6.2_0: give up the tendency to conceit;
ai-sn8:5.2.1_0: “Mendicants, speech that has four factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken.
ai-sn8:5.2.3_0: It’s when a mendicant speaks well, not poorly; they speak on the teaching, not against the teaching; they speak pleasantly, not unpleasantly; and they speak truthfully, not falsely.
ai-sn8:5.2.4_0: Speech with these four factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people.”
ai-sn8:5.2.5_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn8:5.2.6_0: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
ai-sn8:5.3.1_0: “Good people say that well-spoken words are foremost;
ai-sn8:5.3.2_0: second, speak on the teaching, not against it;
ai-sn8:5.3.4_0: and fourth, speak truthfully, not falsely.”
ai-sn8:5.4.1_0: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
ai-sn8:5.4.2_0: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”
ai-sn8:5.4.3_0: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.
ai-sn8:5.4.4_0: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:
ai-sn8:5.5.4_0: such speech is truly well spoken.
ai-sn8:5.6.4_0: that bring nothing bad to others.
ai-sn8:5.7.1_0: Truth itself is the undying word:
ai-sn8:5.7.3_0: Good people say that the teaching and its meaning
ai-sn8:5.8.1_0: The words spoken by the Buddha
ai-sn8:5.8.3_0: for making an end of suffering,
ai-sn8:5.8.4_0: this really is the best kind of speech.”
ai-sn8:6.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn8:6.1.2_0: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dhamma talk. His words were polished, clear, articulate, and expressed the meaning.
ai-sn8:6.1.3_0: And those mendicants were paying heed, paying attention, engaging wholeheartedly, and lending an ear.
ai-sn8:6.1.5_0: “This Venerable Sāriputta is educating the mendicants. ...
ai-sn8:6.1.6_0: And those mendicants were paying heed, paying attention, engaging wholeheartedly, and lending an ear.
ai-sn8:6.1.7_0: Why don’t I extoll him in his presence with fitting verses?”
ai-sn8:6.2.1_0: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward Sāriputta, and said,
ai-sn8:6.2.2_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, please feel inspired to speak.”
ai-sn8:6.2.3_0: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said Sāriputta.
ai-sn8:6.2.4_0: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled Sāriputta in his presence with fitting verses:
ai-sn8:6.3.2_0: expert in the variety of paths;
ai-sn8:6.4.3_0: His call, like a myna bird,
ai-sn8:6.5.2_0: the mendicants listen to his sweet voice,
ai-sn8:7.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother, together with a large Saṅgha of around five hundred mendicants, all of whom were perfected ones.
ai-sn8:7.1.2_0: On one occasion on the observance day, the Buddha was sitting in the open surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.
ai-sn8:7.1.3_0: Then the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of monks, who were so very silent. He addressed them:
ai-sn8:7.1.4_0: “Come now, monks, I invite you all:
ai-sn8:7.1.5_0: Is there anything I’ve done by way of body or speech that you would criticize?”
ai-sn8:7.2.1_0: When he had spoken, Venerable Sāriputta got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:
ai-sn8:7.2.2_0: “There is nothing, sir, that you’ve done by way of body or speech that we would criticize.
ai-sn8:7.2.3_0: For the Blessed One is the one who gave rise to the unarisen path, who gave birth to the unborn path, who explained the unexplained path. He is the knower of the path, the discoverer of the path, the expert on the path.
ai-sn8:7.2.4_0: And now the disciples live following the path; they acquire it later.
ai-sn8:7.2.5_0: And sir, I invite the Blessed One.
ai-sn8:7.2.6_0: Is there anything I’ve done by way of body or speech that you would criticize?”
ai-sn8:7.3.1_0: “There is nothing, Sāriputta, that you’ve done by way of body or speech that I would criticize.
ai-sn8:7.3.3_0: A wheel-turning monarch’s oldest son rightly keeps wielding the power set in motion by his father.
ai-sn8:7.3.4_0: In the same way, Sāriputta rightly keeps rolling the supreme Wheel of Dhamma that was rolled forth by me.”
ai-sn8:7.4.1_0: “Since it seems I have done nothing worthy of the Blessed One’s criticism,
ai-sn8:7.4.2_0: Is there anything that you’ve done by way of body or speech that you would criticize?”
ai-sn8:7.4.3_0: “There is nothing, Sāriputta, that these five hundred monks have done by way of body or speech that I would criticize.
ai-sn8:7.4.4_0: For of these five hundred monks, sixty have the three knowledges, sixty have the six direct knowledges, sixty are freed both ways, and the rest are freed by wisdom.”
ai-sn8:7.5.1_0: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
ai-sn8:7.5.2_0: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”
ai-sn8:7.5.3_0: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.
ai-sn8:7.5.4_0: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:
ai-sn8:7.6.2_0: five hundred monks have gathered together to purify their precepts.
ai-sn8:7.6.3_0: These untroubled sages have cut off their fetters and bonds,
ai-sn8:7.6.4_0: they will not be reborn again.
ai-sn8:7.8.1_0: So the battle Victorious in battle,
ai-sn8:7.8.3_0: he is revered by disciples with the three knowledges,
ai-sn8:7.9.1_0: All are sons of the Blessed One—
ai-sn8:7.9.3_0: I bow to the Kinsman of the Sun,
ai-sn8:7.9.4_0: destroyer of the dart of craving.”
ai-sn8:8.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.
ai-sn8:8.1.2_0: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk.
ai-sn8:8.1.3_0: And those mendicants were paying heed, paying attention, engaging wholeheartedly, and lending an ear.
ai-sn8:8.1.5_0: “The Buddha is educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about extinguishment.
ai-sn8:8.1.6_0: And those mendicants were paying heed, paying attention, engaging wholeheartedly, and lending an ear.
ai-sn8:8.1.7_0: Why don’t I extoll him in his presence with fitting verses?”
ai-sn8:8.2.1_0: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
ai-sn8:8.2.2_0: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”
ai-sn8:8.2.3_0: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.
ai-sn8:8.2.4_0: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:
ai-sn8:8.3.4_0: extinguishment, fearing nothing from any quarter.
ai-sn8:8.4.1_0: They listen to the immaculate Dhamma
ai-sn8:8.4.2_0: as taught by the fully awakened Buddha:
ai-sn8:8.4.4_0: at the fore of the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-sn8:8.6.2_0: out of desire to see the teacher.
ai-sn8:8.7.1_0: “Do you think about these verses? Or do you immediately inspired them?”
ai-sn8:8.7.2_0: “They sprang to mind in the moment, sir.”
ai-sn8:8.7.3_0: “Well then, Vaṅgīsa, speak some more spontaneously inspired verses.”
ai-sn8:8.7.4_0: “Yes, sir,” replied Vaṅgīsa. Then he extolled the Buddha with some more spontaneously inspired verses, not previously composed:
ai-sn8:8.8.3_0: See him, the liberator from bonds, unattached,
ai-sn8:8.9.1_0: He has explained in many ways
ai-sn8:8.9.2_0: the path to cross the flood.
ai-sn8:8.9.3_0: The seers of Dhamma stand unfaltering
ai-sn8:8.9.4_0: in the deathless he has explained.
ai-sn8:8.10.1_0: The bringer of light who has pierced the truth,
ai-sn8:8.10.2_0: you’ve seen what lies beyond all states of being.
ai-sn8:8.10.3_0: When you saw and realized this for yourself,
ai-sn8:8.10.4_0: you taught it first to the group of five.
ai-sn8:8.11.1_0: When the Dhamma has been so well taught,
ai-sn8:8.11.2_0: how could those who know it be negligent?
ai-sn8:9.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn8:9.1.2_0: Then Venerable Koṇḍañña Who Understood approached the Buddha.
ai-sn8:9.1.2_1: and after approaching and falling with their heads at the Buddha’s feet, he caressing them and covering them with kisses, and pronounced his name:
ai-sn8:9.1.3_0: “I am Koṇḍañña, Blessed One! I am Koṇḍañña, Holy One!”
ai-sn8:9.1.5_0: “This Venerable Koṇḍañña searched after a very long time.
ai-sn8:9.1.5_1: and after approaching and falling with their heads at the Buddha’s feet, he caressing them and covering them with kisses, and pronounced his name:
ai-sn8:9.1.6_0: ‘I am Koṇḍañña, Blessed One! I am Koṇḍañña, Holy One!’
ai-sn8:9.1.7_0: Why don’t I extoll him in his presence with fitting verses?”
ai-sn8:9.2.1_0: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
ai-sn8:9.2.2_0: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”
ai-sn8:9.2.3_0: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.
ai-sn8:9.2.4_0: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled Koṇḍañña in the Buddha’s presence with fitting verses:
ai-sn8:9.3.1_0: “The senior monk who was awakened right after the Buddha,
ai-sn8:9.3.3_0: to a happy abiding in gaining material possessions.
ai-sn8:9.5.1_0: With great power and the three knowledges,
ai-sn8:9.5.2_0: expert in comprehending the minds of others,
ai-sn8:9.5.3_0: Koṇḍañña, the heir to the Buddha,
ai-sn8:10.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying on the slopes of Isigili at the Black Rock, together with a large Saṅgha of around five hundred mendicants, all of whom were perfected ones.
ai-sn8:10.1.2_0: Thereupon, with his mind, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna checked to see whose mind was liberated and free of attachments.
ai-sn8:10.1.4_0: “The Buddha is staying on the slopes of Isigili at the Black Rock, together with a large Saṅgha of around five hundred mendicants, all of whom were perfected ones.
ai-sn8:10.1.5_0: Thereupon, with his mind, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna checked to see whose mind was liberated and free of attachments.
ai-sn8:10.1.6_0: Why don’t I extoll him in his presence with fitting verses?”
ai-sn8:10.2.1_0: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
ai-sn8:10.2.2_0: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”
ai-sn8:10.2.3_0: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.
ai-sn8:10.2.4_0: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled Mahāmoggallāna in his presence with fitting verses:
ai-sn8:10.3.1_0: “As the sage, who has gone beyond suffering,
ai-sn8:10.3.3_0: he is revered by disciples with the three knowledges,
ai-sn8:10.5.3_0: who is endowed with all path factors,
ai-sn8:10.5.4_0: and with a multitude of attributes.”
ai-sn8:11.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond, together with a large Saṅgha of around five hundred mendicants, seven hundred male and seven hundred female lay followers, and many thousands of deities.
ai-sn8:11.1.2_0: But the Buddha outshone them all in beauty and glory.
ai-sn8:11.1.4_0: “The Buddha is staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond, together with a large Saṅgha of around five hundred mendicants, seven hundred male and seven hundred female lay followers, and many thousands of deities.
ai-sn8:11.1.5_0: But the Buddha outshone them all in beauty and glory.
ai-sn8:11.1.6_0: Why don’t I extoll him in his presence with fitting verses?”
ai-sn8:11.2.1_0: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
ai-sn8:11.2.2_0: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”
ai-sn8:11.2.3_0: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.
ai-sn8:11.2.4_0: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:
ai-sn8:11.3.1_0: “Like the moon on a cloudless night,
ai-sn8:11.3.2_0: shining like the moon on all sides,
ai-sn8:11.3.3_0: Like this, the great bark of the Ganges.
ai-sn8:12.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Vaṅgīsa was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn8:12.1.2_0: Now at that time Vaṅgīsa had recently attained perfection. While experiencing the bliss of freedom, on that occasion he recited these verses:
ai-sn8:12.2.1_0: “Who did you want to live in first,
ai-sn8:12.2.2_0: village to village, town to town.
ai-sn8:12.3.2_0: the aggregates, sense fields, and elements.
ai-sn8:12.4.1_0: It is for the benefit of many
ai-sn8:12.4.3_0: for the monks and for the nuns
ai-sn8:12.4.4_0: who see that they’ve reached certainty.
ai-sn8:12.5.1_0: It was so welcome for me
ai-sn8:12.5.2_0: to be in the presence of the Buddha.
ai-sn8:12.6.3_0: I am master of three knowledges, attained in psychic power,
ai-sn8:12.6.4_0: expert in comprehending the minds of others.”
ai-sn8:12.7.5_0: And another thousand are the same.
ai-sn8:12.7.8_0: The Linked Discourses with Vaṅgīsa are complete.
